Pain Point: The lack of clarity in the project description hindered me in defining the scope of the model.
It was a challenge to translate the needs of the projects and the stakeholders into model requirements.
I had trouble defining the right level of abstraction and this affected my judgment as to what to include or not in the model.
I did not know the right time to stop modeling.
I could not find any formal technical material (e.g. manuals, books) to consult when I had doubts about the language I had chosen.
I did not know how to increase my model's comprehensibility.
Developing the model was hard because the modeling team was not sufficiently skilled in modeling.
I verified my model but did not understand the errors in it.
I verified my model but did not know how to solve the errors in it.
The model allowed for unintended interpretations and I did not know how to fix it.
The model did not allow for all the intended interpretations and I did not know how to fix it.
I was the only one on the team interested in using and reusing the model.
The model was insufficient to achieve its application objective.
